8.
V Initial Key Stations
Ideally, key stations should be operating in
all of the ten largest cities, since they collectively
cover more than one-half of the nation's population.
Some criteria for selection of the initial key stations
would be these:
1) enthusiasm for the project
2) willingness to commit to the principles
of programming outlined above, including provision of
broadcast time, production facilities, program philosophy,
and so forth,
3) a broadly based community board or community
orientation for the organization holding the educational
FM license or operating permit.
4) adequate technical facilities, including a
minimum of one fully-equipped studio and control for
network multi-microphone origination on demand, portable
recording and remote audio equipment, and transmitter,
recorders and consoles all having stereophonic capability;
FM broadcast range of Grade B signal of a minimum of 30
miles with horizontal and vertical polarization or equivalent
for adequate automobile reception.
Unfortunately, Chicago, Detroit, and Los Angeles do
not have at this moment stations of either sufficient
transmitter power, or commitment or flexibility to particiÂ¬
pate actively as key stations. Groups within these areas
should be encouraged to create such stations. Title I
facilities funds should be sought by the Corporation for
Public Broadcasting to aid in their development.
There appear to be stations in the other major cities
that.do meet most or all of the criteria and who have
expressed a willingness to commit to the idea of the
National Public Radio System - WGBH-FM, Boston; WNYC-FM,
N.Y.C.; WUHY-FM, Phildelphia and KQED-FM, San Francisco.
